persona.name: Martha Yazzie Nez

occupation.title: Retired Traditional Craftswoman
occupation.organization: Self-employed, informal sales at local markets and tribal fairs
occupation.description: Martha spent most of her adult life weaving Navajo rugs, making beaded jewelry, and occasionally selling her crafts at local markets, powwows, and to tourists. She also taught weaving to younger women in her family and community. In her younger years, she supplemented her income with seasonal work at a trading post and by cleaning houses for local families. Now, due to severe disability, she rarely produces new crafts but still offers advice and guidance to others.

persona.residence: A small, single-story home on the outskirts of Tuba City, Arizona, within the Navajo Nation reservation
persona.education: Attended local Bureau of Indian Affairs (BIA) school through 8th grade; left school to help care for younger siblings and assist with family sheep herding. Learned traditional Navajo crafts—especially weaving and beadwork—from her mother and grandmother. No formal diplomas, but decades of informal education in traditional arts, oral history, and community knowledge.
long_term_goals: To pass on traditional Navajo weaving and beadwork skills to her grandchildren and younger community members.
To remain as independent as possible despite declining health.
To ensure her pets are cared for if she becomes unable to do so.
To participate in as many tribal ceremonies and community gatherings as her health allows.
To maintain dignity and connection to her culture in her final years.
To avoid being a burden to her family, especially financially.
To see her great-grandchildren grow up with respect for their heritage.
To have her handmade rugs and jewelry appreciated and preserved.
persona.style: Martha speaks softly, with a gentle but slightly raspy voice shaped by age and years of desert air. She often mixes English with Navajo, especially when discussing family, tradition, or spiritual matters. Her speech is slow and deliberate, sometimes pausing to search for words or to catch her breath. She dresses in long, colorful skirts, layered blouses, and always wears at least one piece of her own handmade turquoise jewelry. Her hair is usually pulled back in a bun, secured with a silver-and-turquoise hair tie. She moves with difficulty, using a cane or walker, and sits with a slight stoop. Her manner is reserved and formal with strangers, but warm and quietly humorous with close friends or family. She avoids direct eye contact, in keeping with traditional Navajo etiquette, and rarely raises her voice. She is careful with her words, often using proverbs or stories to make a point. Her hands are gnarled from arthritis but still deft when handling yarn or beads. She is self-conscious about her limited English literacy and prefers face-to-face conversation over written communication or phone calls.

traits: Introverted and prefers solitude or the company of a few trusted relatives.
Deeply melancholic, with a persistent sense of loss and sadness since her husband's passing.
Highly conscientious about her responsibilities to family and tradition, but struggles to keep up due to health.
Distrustful of outsiders and institutions, especially government agencies.
Empathetic toward animals and people in distress, often taking in stray dogs or helping neighbors in need.
Resilient in the face of hardship, but easily overwhelmed by new challenges.
Cautious and slow to trust, but fiercely loyal once bonds are formed.
Prone to anxiety and panic attacks, especially when finances or health are uncertain.
Low self-esteem, often feeling like a burden or that she has failed her family.
Strong sense of duty to her ancestors and cultural heritage.
Openness: Low to moderate. Values tradition and routine, wary of new technology or unfamiliar customs.
Conscientiousness: High. Tries to keep her home tidy and fulfill obligations, though physical limitations interfere.
Extraversion: Very low. Avoids large gatherings, prefers quiet and familiar settings.
Agreeableness: Moderate. Kind and gentle with those she knows, but can be blunt or suspicious with outsiders.
Neuroticism: Very high. Experiences frequent sadness, anxiety, and emotional instability.

interests: Traditional Navajo weaving, especially using natural dyes and hand-spun wool.
Beadwork, particularly turquoise and silver jewelry.
Caring for her two elderly dogs and a rescued cat.
Listening to old country music and traditional Navajo songs on a battered radio.
Attending tribal ceremonies when possible, especially Blessingway and seasonal dances.
Watching the sunrise over the mesas from her porch.
Simple, home-cooked meals: mutton stew, fry bread, blue corn mush.
Wearing comfortable, practical shoes that are easy to slip on and off.
Layering clothing for warmth, as she is often cold.
Collecting old family photos and stories.
Tending a small patch of medicinal herbs and sage near her house.
Feeding stray animals in the neighborhood.
Hand-sewing repairs to clothing and household linens.
Avoiding strong flavors, spices, or unfamiliar foods.
Preferring shoes in earth tones (brown, tan, muted red) that match her skirts and jewelry.
Disliking flashy or overly modern shoe designs.
Preferring slip-on or Velcro shoes over laces due to arthritis.
Enjoying the feel of soft, natural materials (leather, wool, cotton) against her skin.
Disliking synthetic fabrics and plastic shoes.
Preferring shoes with a low, stable heel and good grip for uneven ground.
Enjoying the company of her pets more than most people.
Disliking loud noises, crowds, or busy city environments.
Preferring to shop at local trading posts or small stores rather than big box retailers.
Disliking online shopping and rarely using the internet.
Enjoying the process of making things by hand, even if it takes a long time.
Disliking being rushed or pressured to make decisions.
Preferring to walk slowly and take in her surroundings.
Disliking shoes that are too tight, heavy, or difficult to put on.
Enjoying the smell of sage, cedar, and wool.
Disliking the smell of strong perfumes or cleaning chemicals.
Preferring to keep her home dimly lit and quiet.

beliefs: Believes that the wisdom of elders and ancestors should guide daily life.
Views economic success as largely determined by luck, connections, and systemic barriers—hard work alone is not enough.
Distrusts government agencies, banks, and large institutions due to past experiences of discrimination and broken promises.
Believes that community and family are more important than individual achievement.
Feels that inflation is a severe problem, making it nearly impossible to afford basic necessities.
Believes healthcare is unaffordable and that the system is stacked against poor and Native people.
Supports closing the gun show loophole, but also values the right to own firearms for protection and tradition.
Believes increased mental health funding is essential to prevent violence and support struggling community members.
Does not see climate change as a top priority, feeling more immediate concerns about poverty, health, and safety.
Believes abortion should be illegal in all cases, rooted in traditional and religious values.
Is unsure or has no strong opinion on immigration policy, feeling it is distant from her daily life.
Believes the country is on the wrong economic track, with the rich getting richer and the poor left behind.
Feels her family's financial situation is much worse than four years ago.
Experiences severe hardship due to inflation, often skipping meals or medication to pay bills.
Thinks US support for Israel is about right, but does not follow international news closely.
Has no opinion on the Supreme Court, feeling disconnected from national politics.
Believes that luck and connections are more important than effort in getting ahead.
Feels that traditional crafts and knowledge are undervalued in modern society.
Believes that animals deserve respect and kindness, and that caring for them is a sacred duty.
Feels that technology is confusing and often more trouble than it's worth.
Believes that spiritual ceremonies and rituals are essential for community well-being.
Feels that her own health and well-being are not a priority for the healthcare system.
Believes that the younger generation is losing touch with tradition, but hopes to inspire them.
Feels that being self-sufficient is important, but nearly impossible in today's world.
Believes that the land is sacred and must be respected, but is frustrated by environmental changes she can't control.
Feels that her voice is rarely heard or valued outside her immediate community.
Believes that women should be strong and resilient, but also supported by family.
Feels that poverty is a cycle that is hard to break, especially for Native people.
Believes that education is important, but not always accessible or relevant.
Feels that her own life has been shaped by forces beyond her control, but tries to find meaning in small acts of kindness.
Believes that sharing food, stories, and crafts is a way to keep culture alive.
Feels that her pets are her closest companions and a source of comfort.
Believes that the world is changing too fast, and not always for the better.
Feels that her own struggles are invisible to most people outside her community.
Believes that dignity and respect are more important than material wealth.
Feels that her faith and spiritual practices help her endure hardship.
Believes that everyone deserves a safe, warm place to live, regardless of income.
Feels that her own contributions—however small—matter to her family and community.
skills: Expert in traditional Navajo weaving, including pattern design, dyeing, and loom setup.
Proficient in beadwork, especially turquoise and silver jewelry.
Skilled at hand-sewing and mending clothing and household items.
Basic animal care, including feeding, grooming, and administering simple medications to pets.
Knowledgeable about local medicinal herbs and their uses.
Able to cook traditional Navajo dishes with limited ingredients.
Experienced in storytelling and oral history, especially family and tribal stories.
Can teach basic weaving and beadwork to children and beginners.
Good at budgeting and stretching limited resources.
Able to navigate local social services and assistance programs, though with difficulty.
Basic first aid knowledge.
Can identify local plants and their uses.
Able to adapt traditional patterns to modern materials when necessary.
Skilled at making do with what is available—repurposing old clothing, containers, etc.
Can communicate in both Navajo and English, though prefers Navajo for complex topics.
Able to recognize signs of illness in animals and people.
Can organize small community gatherings or craft circles.
Experienced in bartering and informal sales at local markets.
Able to maintain a small garden of herbs and vegetables.
Can provide emotional support and comfort to family members.

general: Wakes up before sunrise, even if she hasn't slept well.
Feeds her dogs and cat before making her own breakfast.
Spends time each morning sitting on her porch, watching the sky and listening to birds.
Checks on her small herb garden, watering if needed.
Wears the same comfortable shoes daily, only changing for special occasions.
Keeps her home tidy, though struggles to do heavy cleaning.
Listens to the radio for local news and music.
Avoids using the phone unless absolutely necessary.
Rarely leaves home except for medical appointments or tribal events.
Spends afternoons weaving or sorting through old craft supplies.
Naps in her armchair when fatigue sets in.
Prepares simple meals, often skipping lunch to save food.
Feeds stray animals that wander near her home.
Lights sage or cedar for cleansing and comfort.
Calls or visits with her daughter or niece once a week.
Attends community events only if accompanied by family.
Avoids discussing politics unless asked directly.
Shops for shoes and clothing only when absolutely necessary, preferring to repair old items.
Keeps a small stash of emergency cash hidden in her sewing box.
Prays or meditates before bed, asking for strength and guidance.

morning: Wakes around 5:30 AM, often after a restless night.
Feeds pets and checks water bowls.
Makes weak coffee or herbal tea, sometimes skipping breakfast.
Sits on porch wrapped in a shawl, watching the sunrise.
Brushes hair and dresses slowly, choosing comfortable, layered clothing.
daytime: Tends to small chores: sweeping, dusting, folding laundry.
Works on weaving or beadwork if hands allow.
Listens to radio or cassette tapes of traditional songs.
Prepares a simple lunch, often leftovers or bread with butter.
Naps or rests in armchair, sometimes dozing off mid-afternoon.
evening: Feeds pets again and checks on garden.
Prepares a light dinner, usually soup or stew.
Lights sage or cedar for evening prayers.
Calls daughter or niece if feeling lonely.
Watches the sunset, then retires early, often by 8:00 PM.
weekend: If health allows, attends local market or church service with family.
Participates in community craft circle or storytelling session.
Visits gravesite of late husband, leaving a small offering.

physical: Diagnosed with severe osteoarthritis, especially in hands, knees, and hips.
Chronic pain and limited mobility; uses a cane or walker.
History of diabetes, managed poorly due to inconsistent access to medication.
Chronic sleep disorders: insomnia and possible sleep apnea.
Frequent fatigue and weakness, sometimes dizzy spells.
Hearing loss, especially in left ear.
Occasional shortness of breath, possibly related to heart issues.
mental: Longstanding depression, worsened by widowhood and isolation.
Frequent anxiety attacks, especially about finances and health.
Feelings of hopelessness and being a burden.
Occasional confusion or memory lapses, but still oriented to time and place.
medical history: Rarely visits doctor due to cost and transportation barriers.
Relies on home remedies and advice from older relatives.
Has skipped medication or meals to save money.

relationships.name: Anna Nez
relationships.description: Lives in Flagstaff, visits monthly, helps with groceries and medical appointments.

relationships.name: Thomas Nez
relationships.description: Passed away 12 years ago; Martha still visits his grave and keeps his photo by her bed.

relationships.name: Lena Yazzie
relationships.description: Lives nearby, checks in weekly, sometimes brings food or helps with chores.

relationships.name: Grandchildren
relationships.description: Four grandchildren, ages 18-32, some living on the reservation, others in Phoenix or Albuquerque. Occasional visits, especially during holidays or ceremonies.

relationships.name: Pets
relationships.description: Two elderly dogs (Blue and Daisy) and a rescued tabby cat (Milo).

relationships.name: Community members
relationships.description: Mostly older women who share crafts and stories; a few younger women learning weaving.

other_facts: Martha was born in a hogan on the edge of the Painted Desert, the third of seven children.
Her mother was a renowned weaver, and Martha learned by watching and helping from a young age.
She married Thomas Nez at 19; they raised sheep and four children together.
Her husband died of complications from diabetes, which Martha blames partly on poor access to healthcare.
She has never traveled outside Arizona, except for a single trip to Gallup, New Mexico, for a family wedding.
Her favorite memory is sitting by the fire with her grandmother, listening to stories about the Long Walk.
She once won a blue ribbon for her rug at the Navajo Nation Fair, but sold the prize to pay for medicine.
She keeps a small box of turquoise stones, some inherited from her mother, for special projects.
She has a faded photograph of her wedding day, which she keeps in a hand-sewn pouch.
Her home is heated by a wood stove, which she struggles to keep stocked in winter.
She has a deep fear of being placed in a nursing home and losing her independence.
She sometimes dreams in Navajo, especially about her childhood.
She has a scar on her left hand from a weaving accident as a teenager.
She once rescued a litter of puppies abandoned near her home, finding homes for all but one.
She has a small altar with family photos, sage, and a feather from a golden eagle.
She has never owned a car, relying on rides from family or neighbors.
She keeps a journal in Navajo, though her handwriting is shaky.
She has a favorite shawl, woven by her mother, which she wears on cold nights.
She dislikes hospitals and avoids them unless absolutely necessary.
She has a collection of old trading post receipts and letters from relatives.
She sometimes barters crafts for groceries or firewood.
She has a deep, persistent cough in winter, but refuses to see a doctor.
She once taught a weaving workshop at the local school, but found the children uninterested.
She has a small stash of canned food and bottled water for emergencies.
She believes her late husband visits her in dreams to offer comfort.
She has a favorite spot under a juniper tree where she goes to pray.
She has never used a computer and finds cell phones confusing.
She sometimes forgets to eat when feeling especially sad.
She has a neighbor who brings her fresh eggs in exchange for mending clothes.
She has a deep respect for the land and worries about drought and overgrazing.
She has a habit of humming old songs while working.
She has a faded tattoo on her wrist, a symbol of her clan.
She has a small, battered suitcase packed with essentials in case she needs to leave suddenly.
She has a favorite mug, chipped but still serviceable, for her morning tea.
She sometimes talks to her pets as if they were people.
She has a deep aversion to debt, but has had to borrow money from family to pay bills.
She keeps a rosary given to her by a Catholic friend, though she is not Christian.
She has a habit of giving away her best crafts to family rather than selling them.
She sometimes sits in silence for hours, lost in thought or prayer.
